chapters.introduction: Sets form the foundation of modern mathematics and are used to define relations, functions, probability, and logic.

definitions.set: A well-defined collection of distinct objects
definitions.element: An object belonging to a set
definitions.notation: If x is an element of set A, it is written as x ∈ A

representation_of_sets.roster_form: Elements are listed within curly brackets
representation_of_sets.set_builder_form: Elements are described using a common property

types_of_sets.singleton_set: A set with exactly one element
types_of_sets.finite_set: A set with limited number of elements
types_of_sets.infinite_set: A set with unlimited number of elements
types_of_sets.equal_sets: Sets having exactly the same elements
types_of_sets.equivalent_sets: Sets having the same number of elements
types_of_sets.subset: Set A is a subset of B if every element of A belongs to B
types_of_sets.power_set: Set of all subsets of a given set

operations_on_sets.union: Set of all elements belonging to either A or B
operations_on_sets.intersection: Set of all elements common to both A and B
operations_on_sets.difference: Set of elements belonging to A but not to B
operations_on_sets.complement: Elements not belonging to a given set

venn_diagrams.use: Visual representation of sets and their relationships
venn_diagrams.application: Useful in solving problems involving union, intersection, and complement

chapters.one_liner: Sets look basic, but they quietly control half of Class 11 maths.

chapters.introduction: Relations and functions formalise the idea of dependency between quantities and are central to calculus and higher mathematics.

cartesian_product.definition: Set of all ordered pairs (a, b) where a ∈ A and b ∈ B

relations.definition: A relation is a subset of the Cartesian product of two sets
relations.domain: Set of all first elements of ordered pairs
relations.range: Set of all second elements of ordered pairs

types_of_relations.reflexive: Every element is related to itself
types_of_relations.symmetric: If (a, b) belongs to R, then (b, a) also belongs to R
types_of_relations.transitive: If (a, b) and (b, c) belong to R, then (a, c) belongs to R
types_of_relations.equivalence_relation: Relation that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive

functions.definition: A function is a relation in which every element of the domain has exactly one image in the codomain

types_of_functions.one_one: Distinct elements of domain have distinct images
types_of_functions.many_one: Different elements of domain have same image
types_of_functions.onto: Every element of codomain has a pre-image
types_of_functions.into: Some elements of codomain have no pre-image

graphical_representation.key_idea: Each x has exactly one y-value

chapters.one_liner: Functions are the backbone of calculus—mess this up and Class 11 will humble you.

chapters.introduction: Trigonometry in Class 11 extends beyond ratios to functions, identities, and graphical behaviour, forming the base for calculus and physics.

domain_and_range.tan_sec: Domain excludes odd multiples of π/2

chapters.one_liner: Class 11 trigonometry is not about remembering values—it’s about understanding behaviour.

chapters.introduction: Mathematical Induction is a proof technique used to establish the truth of statements involving natural numbers.

principle.step_1: Prove the statement is true for n = 1
principle.step_2: Assume the statement is true for n = k
principle.step_3: Prove it is true for n = k + 1

logical_basis.assumption: If true for k, then true for k + 1
logical_basis.conclusion: Statement holds for all natural numbers

importance: Used in algorithms and computer science

chapters.introduction: This chapter extends the number system beyond real numbers and provides algebraic tools essential for higher mathematics, physics, and engineering.

complex_numbers.definition: A number of the form z = a + ib, where a and b are real numbers and i^2 = -1
complex_numbers.pure_imaginary_number: When real part is zero (a = 0, b ≠ 0)

algebra_of_complex_numbers.division: Multiply numerator and denominator by conjugate of denominator

conjugate_of_complex_number.definition: If z = a + ib, then its conjugate is a − ib

location_of_roots.method: Using nature of discriminant and sign of coefficients

applications: Solving equations with no real solutions
Foundation for calculus and engineering maths
Used extensively in physics and signal processing
chapters.one_liner: Complex numbers don’t complicate maths—they complete it.

chapters.introduction: This chapter deals with inequalities and their solutions, forming the basis for optimisation problems and higher algebra.

inequality.definition: A mathematical statement comparing two expressions using <, >, ≤, ≥
inequality.linear_inequality: An inequality involving a linear expression

linear_inequalities_in_one_variable.solution: All real values that satisfy the inequality

linear_inequalities_in_two_variables.general_form: ax + by < c, ax + by > c, ax + by ≤ c, ax + by ≥ c

steps: Replace inequality with equality to get boundary line
Test a point to determine the solution region

system_of_linear_inequalities.definition: Set of two or more inequalities considered simultaneously

chapters.introduction: This chapter develops systematic counting techniques, essential for probability, algebra, and discrete mathematics.

fundamental_principle_of_counting.addition_principle: If an event can occur in m ways and another in n ways, total ways = m + n
fundamental_principle_of_counting.multiplication_principle: If an event can occur in m ways and another in n ways, total ways = m × n

permutations.definition: Arrangement of objects where order matters
permutations.permutations_with_repetition: Number of permutations of n objects taken all at a time when repetition is allowed = n^r

circular_permutations.definition: Arrangements of objects in a circle
circular_permutations.note: Clockwise and anticlockwise arrangements are considered same

combinations.definition: Selection of objects where order does not matter

chapters.one_liner: If order matters, permute—if it doesn’t, combine.

chapters.introduction: The Binomial Theorem provides a method to expand expressions of the form (a + b)^n efficiently.

binomial_theorem.statement: (a + b)^n = nC0 a^n + nC1 a^(n−1)b + nC2 a^(n−2)b^2 + ... + nCn b^n

middle_term.when_n_is_odd: Two middle terms at (n+1)/2 and (n+3)/2 positions

chapters.one_liner: Binomial Theorem turns long expansions into structured logic.

chapters.introduction: This chapter studies ordered lists of numbers and the sum of their terms. It is fundamental for calculus, algebra, and financial mathematics.

basic_terms.sequence: An ordered list of numbers following a specific pattern
basic_terms.series: Sum of the terms of a sequence

arithmetic_progression.definition: A sequence in which the difference between consecutive terms is constant
properties: Difference between consecutive terms is constant

geometric_progression.definition: A sequence in which each term is obtained by multiplying the previous term by a constant

arithmetic_mean.definition: A number inserted between two numbers such that all three are in AP

geometric_mean.definition: A number inserted between two numbers such that all three are in GP

common_mistakes: Incorrect identification of a, d, or r
chapters.one_liner: Sequences define patterns—series reveal their total impact.

chapters.introduction: This chapter introduces coordinate geometry of straight lines, forming the base for conic sections and analytic geometry.

basic_concepts.coordinate_plane: A plane formed by the intersection of x-axis and y-axis

slope_of_line.definition: Measure of steepness of a line

chapters.one_liner: Straight lines look simple—but they define all of coordinate geometry.

chapters.introduction: Conic sections study curves obtained by the intersection of a plane with a cone. This chapter builds the analytical foundation for advanced geometry and calculus.

basic_concepts.conic_section: A curve obtained by cutting a cone with a plane
basic_concepts.focus: A fixed point used to define conic curves
basic_concepts.directrix: A fixed line used in the definition of conics
basic_concepts.eccentricity: Ratio of distance from focus to distance from directrix

circle.definition: Set of all points in a plane at a fixed distance from a fixed point

parabola.definition: Set of all points equidistant from a fixed point and a fixed line

ellipse.definition: Set of all points such that the sum of distances from two fixed points is constant

hyperbola.definition: Set of all points such that the difference of distances from two fixed points is constant

chapters.one_liner: Conic sections turn geometry into motion and structure.

chapters.introduction: This chapter extends coordinate geometry from a plane to space, forming the base for vectors and 3D calculus.

coordinates_of_point.interpretation: Position of a point in space

direction_cosines.definition: Cosines of angles made by a line with coordinate axes

chapters.one_liner: 3D geometry teaches maths to think in space.

chapters.introduction: This chapter introduces the fundamental ideas of calculus. Limits describe the behavior of functions near a point, while derivatives measure the rate of change.

limits.definition: The value that a function approaches as the independent variable approaches a particular value

algebra_of_limits.sum_rule: lim [f(x) + g(x)] = lim f(x) + lim g(x)
algebra_of_limits.difference_rule: lim [f(x) − g(x)] = lim f(x) − lim g(x)
algebra_of_limits.quotient_rule: lim [f(x)/g(x)] = lim f(x)/lim g(x), provided denominator ≠ 0

derivatives.definition: Derivative of a function represents the rate of change of the function with respect to its variable

chapters.introduction: This chapter focuses on logical thinking and reasoning, essential for understanding proofs and developing mathematical arguments.

statements.definition: A sentence that is either true or false, but not both

truth_tables.use: Determine truth value of compound statements

chapters.one_liner: Mathematical reasoning trains the brain to think correctly, not quickly.

chapters.introduction: Statistics deals with the collection, analysis, interpretation, and presentation of numerical data. It helps in understanding variability and making informed decisions.

basic_terms.frequency_distribution: Arrangement of data according to frequencies

range.definition: Difference between highest and lowest values

mean_deviation.definition: Average of absolute deviations from mean

variance.definition: Mean of squares of deviations from mean

chapters.one_liner: Statistics doesn’t lie—but careless calculation does.

chapters.introduction: Probability measures the likelihood of occurrence of an event and forms the foundation for statistics and decision-making under uncertainty.

basic_concepts.random_experiment: An experiment with more than one possible outcome

classical_probability.definition: Probability when outcomes are equally likely
classical_probability.formula: P(E) = Number of favourable outcomes / Total number of outcomes

complementary_event.definition: Event that an event does not occur

simple_examples: Drawing a card from a deck
chapters.one_liner: Probability quantifies uncertainty—logic decides the rest.
